In the 19th century, facing persecution in the wake of Western contact, hula was forced to go underground. But thanks to a committed band of caretakers who taught hula in secret, the practice endured. Learn more by checking out our latest blog post: bit.ly/2wq8mFd.

The Rice Festival is an opportunity for people from different cultures to come together and celebrate one of the unique elements that unite them. From food demonstrations to entertainment, this festival will celebrate the world's melting pot, Hawaii and its diversity. The otherwise ordinary grain that is consumed in Hawaii on a daily basis will be transformed and infused with new and fantastic flavors that will tantalize everyone's taste buds. This free, one day event will explore the many different uses for rice, as well as the cultures who use it, and will provide attendees with a deeper appreciation for rice and its many functions. Of course, what would a day of fun be without giving back to those who are less fortunate? A booth will be set up where you will be able to give monetary and brown rice donation to event beneficiary Lanakila Pacific. (Located on Auahi St. in front of Ward Centre.)

Please join us for this special Kona Nui Nights event.  After great success with their first video, Hawaii Aloha, Mana Maoli is back with another epic ʻSong Across Hawaiʻiʻ as part of their Mana Mele Project. "Island Style/ʻŌiwi Ē" was filmed and recorded live across many locations, and is a collaboration with Playing For Change, 4 Miles LLC, 1,000 Hawaiian Charter School youth and dozens of "Mana Mele Collective" artists.

5:30 pm - Opening Oli/Pule - Halau Mele & Hawaiian Charter School youth
5:40 - 6:00 pm - Special guests (TBA)
6:00 - 6:30 pm - Kamakakēhau Fernandez, Pomaikaʻi Lyman and students of Kamakau Public Charter School
6:30 - 6:55 pm - Hālau Ka Liko Pua O Kalaniakea with Kapua Dalire-Moe
7:00 - 7:30 pm - Island Style/OIwi E Video Premiere & live performance feat. Mana Mele artists & Hawaiian charter school youth
7:30 - 8:15 pm - Amy Hanaialiʻi Gilliom
8:15 - 8:55 pm - Taimane, Paula Fuga
9:00 pm - Hawaii Aloha (video & live)
*subject to change

Courtyard Cinema: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton
Thursday, September 14
6:00pm - 9:00pm

Admission is free, tickets required:
http://bit.ly/takeeverywave 

Rory Kennedy's Take Every Wave captures the remarkable and unconventional life of legendary big wave surfer Laird Hamilton. Laird's incredible story began in 1960s Hawaii. Finding solace from an abusive home, he rebelled and funneled his energy into big wave Pipeline surfing, awakening a natural talent. More than an athlete with Hollywood good looks, Hamilton proved himself a true innovator, pushing conventions to the extreme and reinventing surfing throughout his career.

1240 Ala Mona Blvd.
Honolulu, HI 96814
Free parking is available across the street in the T.J. Maxx Parking Garage or at Ward Centre.

Barbecue is about more than grilling a piece of meat. It's a ritual performed religiously across the world. For some it's a path to salvation. Every culture has a form of barbecue. It is the pride of nations. It brings the world together.

Courtyard Cinema: Winter at Westbeth
Thursday, March 9th, 2017
6:00pm - 9:00pm

Admission is free, tickets required: http://bit.ly/CCinemaMar17

Filmed across one extraordinary year in New York City's Westbeth Artists Housing, video artist Edith Stephen (95) hopes to complete an experimental film for her birthday; revered contemporary dancer Dudley Williams (75) rehearses for an electrifying return to the stage; and published poet Ilsa Gilbert (82) faces her impending mortality with revealingly candind poetry. An inspirational story about community, ageing and the need to keep creating.

1240 Ala Mona Blvd.
Honolulu, HI 96814
Free parking is available across the street in the T.J. Maxx Parking Garage or at Ward Centre.

Young Chicago lawyers Michelle Robinson (Tika Sumpter) and Barack Obama (Parker Sawyers) spend a sweltering summer afternoon visitng the art museum, eating lunch together, watching Do The Right Things, getting some ice cream and sharing a first kiss in this dramatization of the President and First Lady's fateful first date. Director Richard Tanne's debut feature premiered at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival.

"There is time, too, for fantasy about what life would be like outside the White House… [Then Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel and] Mr. Obama once imagined moving to Hawaiæi to open a T-shirt shack that sold only one size (medium) and one color (white). Their dream was that they would no longer have to make decisions." 

Join us on Wednesday, for the opening of the Medium White Tee Art installation at Ward Centre, beginning at 6pm. Learn more here > http://bit.ly/2iacn9E

#mediumwhitetee

Please join us for the opening of Medium White Tee, an art installation and pop–up shop selling only white T-shirts in size medium.  Medium White Tee is the fulfillment of President Obama’s reported fantasy of opening a Tshirt shack in Hawaii after his Presidency where the only right answer is one size (Medium) and one color (White).  Free and open to the public, with opening remarks by Maya Soetoro-Ng. 
 
Medium White Tee is a Honolulu Museum of Art off-site installation.  For project information and installation hours click here:  https://honolulumuseum.org/art/exhibitions/16093-medium_white_tee/
